title: 114_hr5480
content: The "Boosting Equity for the American Middle Class Act of 2016" or the "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a refundable credit for early principal payments on certain home mortgages under section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a credit for home mortgage principal payments. The credit allows 50% of excess payments, up to $500 annually, with a lifetime limit of 10 years. There is also a limitation based on modified adjusted gross income. The credit for home mortgage principal payments is limited to not exceed $500 annually and has a lifetime limitation of 10 years. There is also a limitation based on modified adjusted gross income. The credit for home mortgage principal payments is limited based on modified adjusted gross income, with a calculation formula involving specific thresholds and ratios. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is defined as adjusted gross income increased by any amount excluded from gross income under specific sections. Excess home mortgage principal payments refer to the amount of principal paid by the taxpayer exceeding the qualified home mortgage indebtedness for a taxable year. The taxpayer's excess principal payments on indebtedness for a taxable year are calculated by subtracting the actual principal paid from what would have been paid if all required payments were made. This applies to qualified home mortgage indebtedness. The taxpayer must make timely payments under the terms of the indebtedness during the taxable year to qualify as qualified home mortgage indebtedness. The taxpayer must have acquisition indebtedness on their primary residence, which is defined as a traditional mortgage with a term of 15 to 30 years and equal payments. The taxpayer must have acquisition indebtedness on their primary residence, defined as a mortgage with a term of 15 to 30 years and equal payments. No credit is available for married individuals filing joint returns. The credit under this section is adjusted based on changes in interval. For married individuals, no credit is allowed unless they file a joint return. If the credit is allowed for a joint return, the lifetime limitation applies. The credit under this section is adjusted based on changes in interval. If the credit is allowed for a joint return, the lifetime limitation applies to both spouses for that taxable year. The taxpayer can be treated as having received the credit for 10 or more preceding years if both spouses have received such credits. Additionally, excess home mortgage principal payments must be reported for the calendar year. The taxpayer must report excess home mortgage principal payments received during the calendar year. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to include these payments in the calculations for tax credits. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to include excess home mortgage principal payments in tax credit calculations. Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting "36C," after "36B," and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is updated accordingly. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
